Home for mentally disabled ordered to pay for discrimination
 
 
 SAN JOSE, Calif. - A boarding home for mentally disabled homeless people has been ordered to pay $8,200 in damages for discriminating against a lesbian.
 
 Nora Jensen, now 30, moved into the New Beginnings home in April 2003 after treatment for bipolar disorder, according to the state Fair Employment and Housing Commission.
 
 Jensen said she mentioned to manager Juanita Prunty that she was upset because she had broken up with her domestic partner. Prunty replied that she "could not relate" because "homosexuality is an abomination," according to the commission.
 
 The commission said Prunty also prohibited Jensen from using the women's bedroom before 8 p.m. to eliminate the chance of sexual activity with another woman.
 
 "It's just not right to be calling people an abomination," Jensen said. "It's not right to be telling them what they should and shouldn't be doing. She made me feel like I was 3 inches tall."
 
 New Beginnings said Prunty's statement that "homosexuality is an abomination" was protected freedom of religion.
 
 But the commission said in a decision made public this week that Prunty was required to treat residents equally.
